title: Plans for Lunar Bases in Limbo as NASA Mulls Schedule Slip and Program Changes
summary: Revised priorities could delay steps aimed at 'sustainable' moon exploration. NASA is considering extending the timeline to start establishing a base for humans on the moon, potentially disrupting a central element of President Trump's space ambitions.

title: Georgia Postpones Primary Over Coronavirus Concerns
summary: Four states with primaries Tuesday-Arizona, Florida, Ohio and Illinois-assure voters they can safely turn out. States across the country are grappling with how to hold their presidential nominating contests while keeping voters and poll workers shielded from the coronavirus.

title: Trump Steps Up Criticism of Fed
summary: President continues to hammer at Fed policy even after intermeeting rate cut. WASHINGTON-President Trump intensified his criticism of the Federal Reserve on Saturday in light of the coronavirus pandemic and said he has the power to remove or demote Chairman Jerome Powell, even as the Fed is expected to cut rates next week.

title: Morgan Stanley Capital Partners to Sell Vet Hospital Business
summary: Deal marks the latest private-equity investment in the pet-care industry, an increasingly popular sector among private investors. The North American private-equity arm of Morgan Stanley Investment Management has agreed to sell veterinary clinic chain Pathway Vet Alliance LLC to consumer-focused buyout firm TSG Consumer Partners, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: U.S. Expands Europe Travel Ban as Spain Locks Down
summary: Nations world-wide step up border controls and restrictions on movement, seeking to slow pandemic. The Trump administration said it was broadening travel restrictions from Europe to include the U.K. and Ireland, as countries across the globe raced to slow the spread of the coronavirus pandemic and mitigate the economic damage.

title: Iraq Base Housing American Troops Hit by New Strike, Sustaining Tensions
summary: Attack follows U.S. strike on Iran-backed militia. BAGHDAD-Rockets struck an Iraqi base housing American troops on Saturday, lowering any expectations of de-escalation after U.S. strikes on an Iran-backed militia in response to the killing of two of its troops at the same base this week.

title: Diary of a Crazy Week in the Markets
summary: 'It's going to be tough out there': veteran traders, bankers and investors just tried to survive as Wall Street's great bull run ended. It was the wildest week on Wall Street since the 2008 financial crisis.

title: Apple Closes All Its Stores Outside China Over Coronavirus
summary: Its stores inside Greater China, closed previously, were all open Saturday. Apple Inc. will close all its retail stores outside Greater China, a dramatic example of how companies are clamping down on business activity to slow the spread of the coronavirus to their employees and customers.

title: Olympic Swimmers Search for a Place to Train
summary: Many top competitors train at U.S. university facilities that are now closed, with less than 100 days to the Olympic trials. In an Olympic cycle already marked by uncertainty, the nation's top swimmers are grappling with an unprecedented question: Where can they train?

title: What Happens to a Florida Cafe When Customers Stay Away
summary: Costly items that spoil quickly, like lox, are off the menu; search for part-time help is on hold amid coronavirus pandemic. The new coronavirus pandemic is pushing lox off the menu at Turtle Coffee Bar.

title: Nothing Could Deny Liverpool a Championship. Then Coronavirus Stopped Sports.
summary: With the Premier League suspended, the club's fans fear their 30-year wait for a title might never end. The finest minds on Merseyside had been poring over the math for weeks: Which day would Liverpool cap its historic season and clinch its first English league championship in 30 years?

title: Jane Sanders Vows to Push Progressive Ideas 'No Matter Who Is Elected'
summary: Bernie Sanders's wife and political adviser says if he is not the Democratic nominee, she wants to help pull the party to the left. BURLINGTON, Vt.-Jane O'Meara Sanders has helped Bernie Sanders through more than a dozen elections over the years, winning most of them. Now, as the Democratic presidential nomination looks increasingly out of reach for a second time, she is his chief sounding board for determining his next steps.

title: U.S. Suspends Truck-Driving Limits to Speed Coronavirus Shipments
summary: The move comes as hospitals report shortages and retailers and manufacturers strain under surging demand. U.S. highway-safety regulators are suspending rules that limit daily driving hours for truck drivers moving emergency supplies such as medical equipment, hand sanitizer and food in response to the nationwide coronavirus outbreak.

title: Democrats Sharpen Criticism of Trump's Health-Care Policy in Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: Trump administration's changes to Affordable Care Act are targets on campaign trail and in political ads. The coronavirus pandemic is jolting the political debate over health care in the 2020 election campaign, with Democrats arguing the crisis shows the damage the Trump administration has done to the health-care safety net and the need for a larger federal role in providing coverage.

title: China's Markets Still Aren't Immune to the Coronavirus
summary: It is premature to assume that the country where the current pandemic is believed to have originated is now a haven in the storm. U.S. investors largely ignored the spread of the new coronavirus in China. Chinese investors shouldn't make the same mistake as it spreads in the U.S.

title: Low-Wage Workers Struggle as Coronavirus Concerns Spread
summary: New York City's hourly, tip-dependent employees lose work; some still show up despite fears of getting sick. New York City's lowest-paid workers are already feeling the squeeze as concerns over coronavirus exposure keep customers away from restaurants, taxis and other businesses.

title: U.K. Looks to Slow Coronavirus a Different Way
summary: Rather than ban mass gatherings and travel, the government is encouraging people to wash hands and stay home if they are sick. While one government after another announces drastic measures to slow down the spread of the novel coronavirus, the British government is taking a different tack.

title: Who's Most at Risk From the Virus
summary: Tens of millions of Americans are older or have underlying conditions that increase the chance the coronavirus will make them seriously ill. As the new coronavirus spreads around the world, health officials are repeatedly assuring the public: Your risk of getting seriously ill or dying is very low-unless you are older or have an underlying condition.

title: Coronavirus Forces Families to Rip Up Spring Travel Plans
summary: Many people are nixing travel and staying home, or grasping for alternate journeys that might feel safer. For months, Scott and Patrick Soltys-Curry had planned to celebrate their second wedding anniversary with a spring break trip to Dollywood in Tennessee and a visit to Scott's nearby mother and stepfather. But as the new coronavirus started spreading, the family worried about Scott's stepfather, who is 68 and recently had triple bypass surgery.

title: Car-Crash Mystery: Why Can't Drivers Figure Out Roundabouts?
summary: The two-lane circles lead to fewer fatalities and injuries, but more fender-benders. City planners and engineers are stumped over why so many drivers can't handle something as simple as a roundabout.

title: Our Market Reporters Answer Questions From People in Their Lives
summary: If you haven't been tuning into market news, there's no time like the coronavirus crisis to start. Most people know what a recession is. But how about a bear market?

title: Silicon Valley Was First to Send Workers Home. It's Been Messy.
summary: What happens when nearly one million tech employees work from home? Spoiler alert: There have been glitches.. SAN FRANCISCO-Silicon Valley's tech giants are a week ahead of the rest of the country in conducting a nearly million-person, real-time experiment into whether it is possible to operate a fully remote workforce in the age of the coronavirus.

title: Amid 'Ghost Towns,' Students Have Mixed Views About Virus Shutdowns
summary: They understand the gravity of the coronavirus outbreak, even if they are frustrated about having their education-and campus lives-upended. As colleges and universities across the U.S. cancel classes and close campuses in response to the coronavirus epidemic, students are trying to adapt to their new curriculum.

title: What's Quarantined Life Like? China's Nationwide Hibernation Offers a Hint
summary: After weeks cooped up in their homes under coronavirus measures, hundreds of millions have settled into their sequestered lives. BEIJING-When the coronavirus epidemic hit China, Meng Yi's worst fears were that her family would fall ill.

title: 'Rufus Porter's Curious World: Art and Invention in America, 1815-1860' Review: Products of a Failed Polymath
summary: A museum profile of the eccentric inventor, painter, publisher and proselytizer whose endeavors rarely succeeded..

title: U.S. Economic Outlook Hinges on Layoff Decisions
summary: Companies have largely avoided pulling the layoff lever, but pressure to squeeze costs is mounting. The U.S. economic outlook hangs in large part on whether business leaders respond to the new coronavirus crisis as they have with many past shocks: by laying off masses of American workers.

title: Paris Mayoral Candidates Ditch the Usual Kiss on the Cheek as Coronavirus Spreads
summary: The race to see who governs France's capital mirrors how politicians across the world now have to figure out new ways to drum up votes on the campaign trail. PARIS-Mayor Anne Hidalgo was on the stump in an outdoor market, seeking a second term, but there was no pressing the flesh with the public-and certainly no cheek-to-cheek kisses.

title: Trump's Coronavirus Risk Is Low Despite Potential Exposures, His Doctor Says
summary: The president had contact last weekend at Mar-a-Lago with two people who later tested positive. WASHINGTON-President Trump is at low risk of contracting the novel coronavirus and doesn't need to self-quarantine or be tested, his doctor said, despite contact with two people who later tested positive.

title: House Passes Legislation to Combat Coronavirus
summary: Measure would make testing free and provide paid sick leave. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives passed legislation that would make coronavirus testing free and provide paid sick leave to many of those affected by the pandemic spreading across the country.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Viruses That Shaped Our DNA
summary: Many of the traits that make these ultimate parasites so effective at transmitting diseases like Covid-19 also make them an essential part of our own genetic makeup. A virus is the stuff of mystery and fear, an invisibly lurking danger ready to spread explosively around the globe. The new coronavirus, like SARS, MERS and the seasonal flu, enters our bodies, finds its way inside our DNA and commandeers it to make more copies of itself. Viruses are, in many ways, the ultimate parasites.

title: Biden, Coronavirus Produce a Week of Dramatic Changes
summary: American politics is shifting at warp speed, making assumptions dangerous. As the week began, the Democratic presidential contest appeared to be a two-man race, destined to grind on for a while, and President Trump seemed in pretty good shape.

title: What to Watch in Sunday's Democratic Presidential Debate
summary: Biden-Sanders match-up, first one-on-one debate of 2020 race, comes amid coronavirus crisis. WASHINGTON-And then there were two.

title: Your 401(k) May Do a Bit Better This Time
summary: Losses in near-retirement target-date funds in the recent selloff are less serious than in the financial crisis-so far. In 2008, investors were shaken when many in or near retirement saw a significant percentage of their 401(k) balances disappear. Even those in so-called target-date funds, generally designed to minimize large swings close to retirement, saw losses of 25% or more.

title: Covid-19 was a Leadership Test. It Came Back Negative.
summary: One lesson from the coronavirus is that we need leaders who prevent crises more than we need managers who scramble to handle them.. On some glorious day in the future, when the Covid-19 pandemic has been controlled and contained, it will be time to hand out trophies.

title: The Flower Bulbs Gardeners Are Desperate to Buy
summary: The mania for fragrant, delicate snowdrops is not as frenzied as Dutch tulip fever of the 1600s, but an obsession is blooming stateside. MY NOSE just inches above the muddy dirt, I found myself face to face with a clump of pearly white, honey-scented blossoms pushing out of the cold Scottish ground. I had taken the train through the February snow and sleet to see some of the 350 varieties at the snowdrop festival at the Cambo Estate in Fife. Thousands of snowdrops ran riot along woodland walks, and after I took a few spins around the nodding, shimmering drifts, my winter gloom melted.

title: What Nervous Investors Should Watch for Next
summary: From gold to tech to Warren Buffett's next buys, here are pockets of the market to follow closely in the weeks ahead. In a chaotic week for the world, it's been a wild week for markets.

title: Why Supercars Are Doing Away With Windshields
summary: McLaren is experimenting with an air-management system that replaces a windscreen-creating a serene bubble of protection from the elements as you speed along. Dan Neil test-drives the new tech. YOU NEVER SEE snow globes from the inside.

title: FAA Probes Problem With Southwest Jet
summary: Crack in fuselage during flight prompts reassessment of maintenance checks for certain Boeing 737 models. U.S. air-safety officials are investigating potential structural problems affecting hundreds of Boeing 737 jets following an in-flight incident that left a 12-inch rupture in the aluminum skin of a Southwest Airlines plane.

title: U.S. Policy Makers Weigh Next Stage of Stimulus
summary: Congress is working on a broader economic response to coronavirus pandemic that would go beyond package currently being negotiated. WASHINGTON-U.S. policy makers are contemplating a significant fiscal stimulus to protect businesses and consumers from the economic disruptions caused by the coronavirus epidemic, with talks on the size, speed and composition of such an effort in the early stages.

title: Town Halls, Fundraisers Go 'Virtual' as Virus Disrupts 2020 Campaign
summary: Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders have curtailed the kind of retail politics that has marked every modern White House campaign. WASHINGTON-No rallies. No handshakes. No in-person fundraisers. And a whole lot of uncertainty.

title: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau Says He Is 'Feeling Fine'
summary: Trudeau says he has no flu-like symptoms less than a day after his wife tested positive for coronavirus. OTTAWA-Canadian authorities on Friday were investigating those who had potentially been exposed to the coronavirus through contact with the wife of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who said he remains in good health and doesn't plan to be tested.

title: Federal Government Urged to Close Offices
summary: Some agencies have issued only temporary or partial recommendations for civil servants. WASHINGTON-Federal workers, lawmakers and some government health experts stepped up calls for the Trump administration to close government offices to help contain the spread of the new coronavirus in the U.S.

title: Bank of America, American Airlines, Walt Disney: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are 14 major companies whose stocks moved on this week's news.. Occidental Petroleum Corp.

title: Chenault Leaves Facebook Board After Disagreements With Zuckerberg
summary: Board member disagreed with founder over governance and political policies. Kenneth Chenault will be leaving Facebook Inc.'s board of directors following disagreements with Mark Zuckerberg over the company's governance and political policies, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Medicaid Curbs for States Are Eased to Deal With Coronavirus Spread
summary: Leaders saw need for waivers and increased federal matching funds ahead of likely increase in demand for health care. States will get more Medicaid and Medicare flexibility following President Trump's emergency declaration Friday so they can respond to the likely increase in demand for health care as the new coronavirus spreads and a sinking economy creates more enrollment demands.

title: Companies Have Discretion Over Whether to Disclose Coronavirus Infections
summary: Firms may have a strong incentive to disclose medical information to prevent leaks or questions from investors. Companies are thinking through how or even whether they would disclose potential Covid-19 infections of executives.
